subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Terminal unstressed -ior & terminal -ion (with y-sound)
msgSnippet: ... From: kyudosha  ... While I m not a normal peruser of this group, you re probably not a normal peruser of the shavian yahoogroup
messageBody:
----- Original Message -----
From: "kyudosha" <kyudosha@...>


> The a-vowel in "cAlm" and "whAt" both use the same letter and sound
> quite similar in British English as near as I can tell, so why not
> combine them as T.O. did?

While I'm not a normal peruser of this group, you're probably not a normal
peruser of the "shavian" yahoogroup that runs in parallel with this one. If
you look at the topics recently running there, you'll see that this "on
versus ah" issue (as we refer to it there) has been debated for months, if
not years.

It is true that many American English speakers do not make a distinction
between the two in their speech. But most major dictionaries there list a
difference in their pronunciation guides so it's not hard to look up where
differences occur. But for those people who just don't see it, in practical
terms, the rule we agreed upon in the Shavian group was to use the 'on'
letter ('ox' in QS) for any word where that sound is heard, and simply
memorise the few words that use 'ah' (e.g. father, lather, calm, palm,
etc.).

I developed a 'subset' of Shavian that did away with the "on/ah" difference
amongst other alterations, purely as an experiment to see if it would be a
viable 'easier' alternative. It was much closer to QS in many ways but used
Shavian letterforms. It's never been seriously tested by anyone but myself.
I'll try to find a table of characters and post it.

Hugh B
